Chapter 9: Kirchhoff's Loop Rule

The Energy Hike

Imagine you're hiking a mountain trail that loops back to where you started. You might climb up a hill and descend a slope, but your net change in altitude is always zero.

Electric circuits work the same way!

Potential Checkpoints

Look at the circuit on the right. There are 4 checkpoints labeled A, B, C, D.

Click each one in order to see how the potential changes as a charge "walks" around the loop.

Climbing the Battery

When a charge passes through the battery (A → B), it gains potential energy. The EMF "lifts" it up.

\(\Delta V_{AB} = +\mathcal{E}\)

Descending the Resistors

When a charge passes through a resistor, it loses potential energy. The drop equals \(IR\).

\(\Delta V = -IR\)

Conclusion

After visiting all checkpoints and returning to A, the sum of all voltage changes is exactly zero:

\(\sum \Delta V = 0\)

This is Kirchhoff's Voltage Law—energy conservation for charges.
